metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of ground truth measurement synchronizing with the airborne microwave radiometers (L&K bands) mission in the Biandukou foci experimental area on Mar. 19, 2008
metadata.description:
The dataset of ground truth measurement synchronizing with the airborne microwave radiometers (L&K bands) was obtained in the Biandukou foci experimental area from 11:20 to 12:30BJT on Mar. 19, 2008. Observation items included:
     (1) the frost depth by the chopstick and the ruler. The soil was considered frozen when it was hard and with ice crystal. The data can be opened by Microsoft Office Word.
     (2) the surface radiative temperature by the handheld infrared thermometer and the physical temperature by the thermocouple. The data can be opened by Microsoft Office Word.
     (3) the soil moisture (soil samples from 0-1cm, 1-3cm and 3-5cm) by the microwave drying method. The data can be opened by Microsoft Office Word.
     (4) photos of each sampling point in .jpg for further reference.
     Six data files were included, the ground-based K-band microwave radiometer, the ground-based L-band microwave radiometer, the frost depth, soil moisture, the surface temperature and the surface conditions.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the properties of the data collection methods used for measuring soil freeze-thaw depth and surface temperature in microwave radiometry?
Feature Specification.Answer: inserted chopstick to sense soil hardness, excavation to measure frozen soil thickness, handheld infrared thermometer, thermocouple thermometer, needle-type platinum resistance thermometer

Quantification.Question: How many parameters are measured during the airborne microwave radiometer experiments to assess soil conditions?

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of conducting airborne L&K band microwave radiometer experiments to observe soil moisture and soil freeze-thaw states?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main purpose is to observe the impact of soil moisture and freeze-thaw conditions on microwave radiation. This involves measuring surface parameters such as surface radiation temperature, physical temperature, soil moisture at various depths, and freeze-thaw depth to understand their effects on microwave radiometer readings.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to measure soil freeze-thaw depth and how is the data recorded and validated?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Soil freeze-thaw depth is measured by inserting chopsticks into the soil to feel hardness or by excavating the soil surface frozen layer to measure the frozen layer's thickness. A ruler is used for direct measurement. If the soil is found hard with ice crystals, it is considered frozen; otherwise, it is unfrozen. The data can be opened using Microsoft Office software.
